The capital improvements element and schedule of capital improvements may recognize and include transportation projects included in the first three years of the applicable, adopted state department of transportation five-year work program. 
B.  Five-year schedule of capital improvements which must include both necessary facilities to maintain the adopted level of service standards to serve the new development proposed to be permitted and the necessary facilities required to eliminate those portions of existing deficiencies which are a priority to be eliminated during the five-year period under the local government plan's schedule of capital improvements, pursuant to F.A.C. 9J-5.016(4)(a)1. 
C.  A realistic, financially feasible-funding system based an currently available revenue sources which must be adequate to fund the public facilities required to serve the development authorized by the development order and development permit, and which road improvements are included in the county or city five-year schedule of capital improvements. 
D.  A five-year schedule of capital improvements that must demonstrate that the actual construction of the road are scheduled to commence in or before the third year of the five-year schedule of capital improvements. 
E.  The requirement for a plan amendment to eliminate, defer or delay construction of any road which is needed to maintain the adopted level of service standard and which is listed in the five-year schedule of capital improvements. 
Section 4.4. - Concurrency administration. 
    The development services department shall be responsible for the following primary tasks associated with administration of this chapter. 
A.  Creating and maintaining an inventory of existing public facilities capacities or deficiencies; 
B.  Reviewing concurrency assessments and recommending conditions of approval for major development applications; and 
C.  Annually reporting the status of all public facilities capacities covered under this chapter to the city council. Said report shall be prepared in conjunction with the annual budget hearing. 
Section 4.5. - Adopted level-of-service standards. 
    The adopted level of service standards for those public facilities for which concurrency is required shall be as established in the city's comprehensive plan, and as follows: 
4.5.1.  Transportation. 
A.  State Arterials      Peak Hour LOS 
1.  US 17-92 (Principal)       C 
2.  SR 472 (Minor)       C 
B.  County Arterials      Peak Hour LOS 
1.  Enterprise Road       E 
2.  Graves Avenue       E 
3.  Kentucky Avenue       E 
4.  Veterans Memorial Parkway       E 
5.  Saxon Boulevard       E 
C.  County Collectors      Peak Hour LOS 
1.  Blue Springs Avenue       E 
2.  Carpenter Avenue       E 
3.  French Avenue       E 
D.  Orange City shall allow development to occur along the following state maintained roadways that are determined to be backlogged facilities, provided that such development will not increase peak hour traffic volumes by more than 20 percent above the most recent traffic count prior to adoption of the comprehensive plan. 
Roadway 
Segment Acceptable LOS US 17-92 C  
E.  All traffic concurrency analysis shall be performed by using the Florida Standard Urban Transportation Modeling System (FSUTMS) and the standard Florida Department of Transportation methods for evaluation of LOS and capacity shall be used, subject to modifications based on travel speed studies. 
4.5.2.  Potable water. 
A.  300 gallons per day per equivalent residential connection. 
B.  1,500 gallons per day per acre for commercial/industrial/institutional uses. 
C.  500 gallons per minute fire flow. 
4.5.3.  Sanitary sewer. 
A.  Two hundred eighty-four gallons per day equivalent residential connection or that required by the county whichever is greater. 
B.  Eight one-hundredths gallons per day per square foot for industrial, commercial and/or institutional uses or that required by the county whichever is greater. 
4.5.4.  Solid waste. Six pounds per capita per day. 
4.5.5.  Stormwater drainage. 
A.  Developments of less than one acre with less than 5,000 square feet of impervious area, or an impervious area is less than 25 percent of the total lot area shall meet the performance and design standards of Article VIII, Stormwater Management, Volusia County Land Development Code, Ordinance 88-3, as amended. 
B.  Development of any lot area that consists of 5,000 or more square feet of impervious area or, the impervious area is 25 percent or more of the total lot area: or, the lot area of the proposed development is one acre or larger regardless of the impervious area shall meet additional performance standards of Article VIII, Stormwater Management, Section 804(3)(a) and (b) of the Volusia County Land Development Code, Ordinance 88-3, as amended. 
C.  The following development activities are exempt from the performance and design standards of Article VIII, Stormwater Management, of the Volusia County Land Development Code, Ordinance 88-3, as amended. 
1.  Single-family and duplex residences and accessory structures; 
2.  Bona fide agricultural pursuits including forestry, except where artificial drainage will be used to increase the flow of surface water from the applicant's land; 
3.  Maintenance work performed on existing mosquito control drainage canals for the purpose of public health and welfare; 
4.  Maintenance work on utility or transportation systems provided such maintenance work does not alter the purpose and intent of the drainage system as constituted; 
5.  Any maintenance, alteration, renewal, use or improvements to an existing structure not changing or affecting rate or volume of stormwater runoff and the one-time construction of any structure or addition not otherwise exempt, not exceeding 1,000 square feet of impervious area on a parallel to the ground; 
6.  Notwithstanding any other provision of Article VIII of the Volusia County Land Development Code, Ordinance 88-3, as amended, there shall be no harmful erosion by water of any soil or fill onto any adjacent public or private property. 
4.5.5.  Recreation. 
A.  Community park: Four acres per 1,000 population. 
B.  Neighborhood park: Two acres per 1,000 population. 
C.  The city shall utilize the existing LOS for recreation facilities, contained in Table 6.4 of the comprehensive plan support document, as guidelines in developing future park sites. 
Section 4.6. - Improvements, renovations and repair. 
    Improvements, renovations and repair to existing structures shall only effect facility capacity and concurrency to the extent such improvements, renovations, and repairs increase the number of dwelling units, floor area for nonresidential uses or other measures of intensity. In such cases where improvements, renovations, repair and reuse to existing structures will result in a probable increase in either density or intensity of the property or development, then a determination of such an increase and its effect on facility capacity shall be made prior to any approval for a development permit. If existing facility capacity is available and no degradation of adopted service levels for those facilities identified in section 4.2.1 of this chapter will result from such an improvement, a development permit may be issued. If such improvements, renovations and repairs will not result in any increase in density or intensity, then the issue of sufficient facility capacity and concurrency will have no bearing on the issuance of a development permit. 
Section 4.7. - Modifications, amendments or additions. 
    Modifications, amendments or additions to the approvals specified under this chapter during the planning period that would result in an increase in density or intensity in the properties shall be tested for facility capacity for the additional density or intensity identified. 
Section 4.8. - Concurrency review process. 
    The development services department shall be responsible for conducting all concurrency reviews as required by this chapter. Concurrency review shall be initiated upon receipt of a completed concurrency review form provided by the development services department and accompanied by a concurrency review fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. The department may also conduct concurrency reviews for developments in the preapplication or sketch plan stage, and issue a nonbinding letter of concurrency findings. Such requests for concurrency review shall require the submission of a concurrency review fee as established by resolution of the city council. 
4.8.1.  Application. All development applications unless exempted by sections 4.2.2 and/or 4.2.3 of this chapter shall include a completed concurrency review form that is completed by the applicant and containing the following information: 
A.  Traffic impact study. Unless exempted by section 4.2.2. and/or 4.2.3. of this code, all new developments shall be required to submit a traffic analysis, which identifies the development's impact on the city's transportation system. The development services department may also require the submission of a traffic analysis for developments whose site location, anticipated total trip generation, circulation patterns or other such factors warrant a more extensive review of traffic impacts. Such an analysis shall include the following: 
1.  Total projected average daily trip ends for the proposed development. [2] 
2.  Average projected peak-hour trip ends generated by the development. [3] 
3.  Design capacity of the accessed road. 
4.  Analysis of traffic distribution on the road network including all links impacted by more than 500 trips per day. 
5.  Projected percentage of truck and bus traffic. 
6.  Necessary operational improvements to the city's transportation system in order to maintain the appropriate level-of-service for the roadway. 
7.  Other related information as required by the DSD. 
B.  Description and estimate of water use needs. 
C.  Description and estimate of wastewater generation. 
D.  Description and estimate of solid waste generation. 
E.  Stormwater drainage calculations. 
F.  Other information required by the DSD to conduct a complete and accurate review. 
Review and approval of a proposed development may be postponed for a reasonable time period in order for required information to be assembled. Failure of the applicant to provide adequate information on the anticipated project impacts in a timely fashion, however, shall constitute sufficient grounds to deny the project. 
4.8.2.  Project impact assessment. 
A.  Existing conditions. To conduct the assessment of the anticipated impacts of a proposed development on public facilities, the applicant shall use the development services department's inventory of public facilities capacities as a base for the establishment of existing conditions. 
B.  Impact assessment. Using the information provided as required by section 4.8.1.A. through F., the applicant shall calculate the anticipated impacts of the proposed development for all applicable public facilities. The impacts of the proposed development shall then be assessed against the existing conditions established above. 
4.8.3.  Determination of availability. In determining the availability of public facilities or services, a developer may propose, and the city may approve, developments in stages or phases so that public facilities and services needed for each phase will be available in accordance with the standards required by Sections 9J-5.0055(2)(a), (2)(b) and (2)(c), F.A.C. 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Note- The latest edition of the institute of traffic engineers (ITE) trip generation manual shall be used to calculate these estimates. Adjustments to these estimates may be made, based on special trip generation information supplied by the applicant. 

--- (3) --- 
Note- The latest edition of the institute of traffic engineers (ITE) trip generation manual shall be used to calculate these estimates. Adjustments to these estimates may be made, based on special trip generation information supplied by the applicant. 

Section 4.9. - Concurrency findings. 
    Upon the conclusion of the concurrency review, the DSD shall prepare a written set of findings, as appropriate, concerning the proposed development. These findings shall include, but are not limited to: 
A.  The anticipated public facility impacts of the proposed development; 
B.  The ability of existing facilities to accommodate the proposed development at the adopted level of service standards; 
C.  Any existing facility deficiencies that will need to be corrected prior to the completion of the proposed development; 
D.  The facility improvement or additions necessary to accommodate the impacts of the proposed development at the adopted level of service standard and the entity responsible for the design and installation of all required facility improvements or additions; 
E.  The date such facility improvement or additions will need to be completed to be concurrent with the impacts on such facility created by the proposed development. 
Section 4.10. - Concurrency reservation. 
4.10.1.  Capacity reservation. If the concurrency findings in section 4.9 reveal that the capacity of public facilities is equal to or greater than that required to maintain the adopted level-of-service for said facilities, the DSD shall reserve public facility capacity necessary for the proposed development. Capacity reservations shall be made on a first-come, first-served basis, based on the date of project approval. Concurrency shall be reserved in conjunction with a development order and shall be valid only for the specific land used, densities, intensities, and construction and improvements contained in the development order and any applicable development agreements approved for the development. A finding of concurrency shall reserve public facility capacity for the length of the development order. If the development order expires, the capacity reservation will expire on the same expiration date of the development order. For planned unit development, public facility capacity may be reserved for the first phase of the project for up to one year from the date of approval of the development agreement. Properties with approvals specified under this section shall have facility capacity reserved for such properties during the duration of the planning period unless previous agreements provide for an earlier expiration date. Capacity reservations for concurrency shall expire if the underlying developments order or development agreement expires or is revoked. 
4.10.2.  Project deferral/development moratoriums. If at any time the city's inventory of public facilities capacities indicates that a public facility has dropped below it's adopted level service, then the city shall cease to issue development orders for projects that would impact the deficient facility. Such a suspension or moratorium on the issuance of development orders shall continue until such time as the adopted LOS standard is reestablished or the comprehensive plan is amended to reflect a lower, acceptable community standard for the facility in question. However, the city may allow an applicant to proceed with the project not withstanding a failure of the development due to satisfying transportation concurrency provided the provisions of F.S. § 163.3180(11) can be met. 
4.10.3.  Concurrency denials. In the event that the concurrency review reveals that the proposed development would generate public facility impacts beyond that which can be absorbed by available capacity, the city shall ensure that there is a financial or other legally binding commitment to ensure that public facilities necessary to correct the anticipated deficiency will be in place concurrent with the impacts of the proposed development. Should the city and/or a developer be unable to provide such assurances, the project shall be denied. Projects denied due to failures to meet requirements, but for which all other land development requirements have been met, shall be placed on a prioritization list for approval of development orders once facility improvements have been made. 
4.10.4.  Deferrals and denials related to traffic LOS. For deferrals or denials related to traffic LOS, the city may allow an applicant to proceed with the project not withstanding a failure of the development due to satisfying transportation concurrency provided the provisions of F.S. § 163.3180(11) can be met. 
CHAPTER 5. - DEVELOPMENT ORDERS, DEVELOPMENT PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY 

Section 5.1. - Issuance of development orders and development permits. 
    No person shall undertake the development of land within the corporate limits of the City of Orange City except pursuant to a valid development permit issued as required by this code unless specifically exempted as provided by this code. A development permit may not be issued unless authorized by a development order that meets the requirements of this code and said permit meets any other applicable requirements. A development order for a proposed development shall be issued only in conjunction with the approval of either a site plan or a preliminary subdivision plat wherein the applicant will install all subdivision improvements in the manner prescribed by this code prior to final subdivision plat approval. If the subdivision improvements are not installed prior to final subdivision plat approval, then the development order shall be issued only in conjunction with the approval and recording of the final subdivision plat. The issuance of a development order shall authorize issuance of appropriate development permits that meet the regulation of this code and any other application of requirements. An approved tree removal and/or approved stormwater development permit, upon issuance, shall authorize commencement of site work. 
Section 5.1.1. - Performance and maintenance guarantees. 
    As a condition for the issuance of any development order, either in conjunction with a site plan and/or subdivision plat, the applicant shall provide the city with a guarantee of performance of the development order relating to infrastructure. 
A.  In lieu of installing required improvements prior to the approval of a final plat, or the issuance of a certificate of occupancy (or its functional equivalent), a developer may guarantee installation of improvements by providing performance bond, escrow, or irrevocable letter of credit, in an agreement form approved by the city attorney. Such surety shall cover at least 110 percent of the cost of all required improvements such as streets, utilities, drainage structures, landscaping, or others as required by the land development code, with estimates provided by the developer and approved by the city engineer. The surety shall be conditioned upon faithful performance by the developer of the work required to be complete all improvements in the development, in compliance with these regulations, and shall be payable to and for the indemnification of the city. Portions of the guarantee may be released to the developer proportionate to the work completed from time to time as work progresses. The amount to be released shall be determined by the city engineer. Upon approval of all required improvements by the city engineer, the city council shall accept any improvements to be publicly dedicated and a maintenance guarantee shall be established as set forth in this section. 
B.  Following the dedication of the required improvements, the city shall provide routine maintenance. However, the developer shall continue to be responsible for the repair, reconstruction and/or replacement of all improvements due to defects in design, materials and/or workmanship for a period of one year after dedication to the city. This guarantee shall be in the amount of 15 percent of the construction cost of the improvements as provided by the engineer of record and approved by the city engineer. Should the city engineer find defects in design, material and/or workmanship during the maintenance period as herein specified, the city engineer shall notify the developer in writing, giving the developer 15 days to take corrective action. Should the developer fail to take corrective action within 15 days, the city may correct the problem, deducting the cost from the maintenance guarantee. At the end of the maintenance guarantee period, if all requested repairs, reconstruction and/or replacement of improvements have been completed to the satisfaction of the city engineer, the city council shall release the developer and surety from any further obligation under the terms of the maintenance guarantee. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 1, 1-11-05; Ord. No. 569 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 569 , § 2(Exh. A), adopted April 25, 2017, changed the title of § 5.1.1 from "Predevelopment requirements" to read as herein set out. 
Section 5.2. - Development order exceptions. 
    A development permit may be issued without a development order for the following development activities, when the proposed development conforms to the applicable standards and permitting requirements of this code: 
A.  The construction, alteration or enlargement of a one- or two-family dwelling on an existing lot of record prior to the adoption of this code. 
B.  The construction of an accessory structure on a previously developed single-family lot. 
C.  The alteration of an existing structure that does not enlarge the effective size or capacity of the structure. 
D.  Demolition of a structure. 
E.  Erection of signs, fences or walls on a previously developed site. 
F.  Erection of signs, fences or walls when not undertaken in conjunction with other development activity on the site. 
G.  The installation of an irrigation system on an existing one- or two-family lot or previously developed site. 
H.  The clearing or planting of trees or vegetation, changing of grade or alteration of wetlands when not undertaken in conjunction with other development activity on the site. 
I.  The resurfacing of an existing vehicle use area in conjunction with a prior approved site plan. 
J.  The installation of an antenna on a communication tower that complies with the requirements of this code. 
Section 5.3. - Conditions for issuing development orders and permits. 
    All development orders and permits are issued contingent upon the following conditions: 
A.  The accuracy of information provided in the approved application and exhibits. Inaccuracies that affect compliance with this code or the soundness of engineering design may be considered grounds for the voiding of a development order or permit. 
B.  Copies of all applicable approved permits from federal, state, regional and county agencies with jurisdiction over any portion of the proposed development shall be provided to the DSD prior to the issuance of a development order. 
C.  Comply with requirement of this code. 
Section 5.4. - Expiration of a development order. 
    All development orders shall have an expiration date clearly noted, after which time the development order shall expire if no development permit has been issued. Expiration dates shall be as follows. 
A.  Development orders for subdivision preliminary plats and final plats or site plans shall expire one year from the date of issuance by the DSD. 
B.  Development orders for planned unit development (PUD) zoning approvals shall expire based on the terms of the PUD development agreement and any phasing plan therein. 
C.  Variances shall expire based on the conditions of approval, or if none, then the expiration shall be based on the specific requirements of chapter 3 of this code. 
D.  Conditional uses shall expire based on the conditions of approval or if none, then the expiration shall be based on the specific requirements of chapter 3 of this code. 
E.  Supplemental uses that were approved prior to the effective date of this code shall expire when the initial supplemental use is abandoned, transferred or sold. 
F.  Rezonings, except rezoning to PUD zoning districts, shall have no expiration date. 
Section 5.5. - Extension of expiration date. 
    Where an extension of a development order expiration date is desired, the applicant shall request an extension in writing to the DSD prior to the expiration date of said development order. The request for extension shall be accompanied by an appropriate fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. The first request for extension shall be reviewed and considered by the DSD who may allow and approve an extension for a maximum of up to one year, without city council approval. Thereafter, an applicant may request additional one year extensions of a development order only from the city council. However, no development order shall be extended for more than a total of seven years from the original date of expiration. The afore described extensions shall be otherwise reviewed and considered by the same process as the original approval, with special consideration to the following: 
A.  If any amendment to this code is made after approval of the original development order and would necessitate modification of the original approved development plans or associated documents. 
B.  Re-evaluation of the ability of the proposed development to meet the concurrency management requirements of this Code. 
C.  Changes in surrounding land use, development or other conditions that may require modification of the application to meet the requirements of this Code. 
D.  Statutory development agreements may be extended as set forth in Section 163.3229, Fla. Stat., as it may be amended. 
(Ord. No. 379, § 1, 4-28-09) 
Section 5.6. - Modification of a development order. 
5.6.1.  Minor modifications. Minor modifications to development orders may be approved by the DSD when such modifications are consistent with the requirements of this code and do not have a substantial impact on the overall impact and intent of the development order. The following modifications shall be generally considered as minor. 
A.  Dimensional changes to accommodate field conditions, provided said changes do not violate zoning district dimensional requirements or buffer requirements of this code. 
B.  Changes of landscape or construction materials that are deemed to be similar or equivalent to those approved. 
C.  Technical changes to construction details. 
5.6.2.  Major modifications. Proposed modifications that do not meet the criteria described above shall be considered major modifications. Major modifications shall be submitted for approval under the same procedure as required for the original approval and be accompanied by the appropriate fee as established by resolution of the city council. 
Section 5.7. - Development permit issuance. 
    Development permits may be issued as follows: 
A.  A development permit may be issued only upon approval of a development order as required by this code. 
B.  Development permits for buildings related to an approved subdivision plat, except for model homes and/or construction buildings in compliance with the provisions of chapter 6 shall only be issued after the final subdivision plat is recorded. Development permits shall only be issued upon a determination by the chief building official that said buildings, including model homes and construction buildings, comply with the city's building and construction codes. 
C.  Development permits for buildings related to an approved site plan development order shall only be issued upon a determination by the chief building official that said buildings comply with the city's building and construction codes. 
D.  Development permits for signs, walls and fences, irrigation systems, structures on existing lots of record prior to the adoption of this code, and grading and/or land clearing not associated with an approved site plan or subdivision plat shall be issued pursuant to section 5.2 of this chapter. 
Section 5.8. - Development permit retention. 
    The DSD shall maintain a record of all development permits for at least five years, or as otherwise required by state law. 
Section 5.9. - Certificates of occupancy. 
    A certificate of occupancy (CO) to use or occupy a premise requiring site plan approval shall not be issued without first having submitted to the DSD an as-built survey or certification from the engineer of record as to the completion of all on-site and off-site improvements required by any applicable development order. Said survey shall be provided in both paper copy and computer compact disk format acceptable to the DSD. Upon a determination by the DSD that all such improvements have been completed, and that the premises sought to be occupied have fully complied with the provisions of the Land Development Regulations and/or the Comp. Plan of the City of Orange City, a CO may be issued by the CBO. The development services department shall maintain a record of all COs for at lease five years, or as may otherwise by required by state law. The DSD may authorize a bonded temporary CO if some of the on-site improvements required by the development order are otherwise provided by a performance bonds, escrow funds, or other surety acceptable to the DSD. The applicant for a temporary CO shall sign a hold harmless agreement with the city that is approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04; Ord. No. 290, § 1, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 5.10. - Enforcement of development orders. 
    All development orders and permits, including but not limited to, site plans and/or subdivision plats, may be enforced pursuant to section 3.13.2 of this Land Development Code. 
(Ord. No. 244, § 1, 5-10-05) 
CHAPTER 6. - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS 

Section 6.1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to assist implementation of the city's comprehensive plan authorized by F.S. ch. 163 by establishing procedures and standards for the subdivision and development of land within the city. These regulations are intended to aid in the coordination of land development in accordance with orderly physical patterns; to discourage haphazard, premature, uneconomic or scattered land development; to encourage development of economically stable and healthful communities; to ensure proper identification, monumentation and recording of real estate boundaries; to ensure to the purchaser of land in a subdivision that adequate and necessary physical improvements of lasting quality will be installed by the developer and ensure that citizens and taxpayers will not bear this cost; to provide for safe and convenient traffic circulation; to provide an efficient, adequate and economic supply of utilities and services to new land developments; to prevent periodic or seasonal flooding through flood control measures and drainage facilities; to provide public open spaces in new land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; to help conserve and protect physical, economic and scenic resources; to promote the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. 
Section 6.2. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to any division of land as follows: 
A.  No lot shall be sold, no subdivision shall be platted or recorded, and no development permit shall be issued unless the subdivision meets all the applicable laws of the state and has been approved or determined exempt in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
B.  The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to any land forming part of a subdivision created and recorded prior to effective date of this code, but it shall apply to any re-subdividing of previously recorded subdivisions and any new subdivisions. 
C.  Developments that have received preliminary plat approval prior to the effective date of this code and are recorded within 180 days following the effective date of this code shall not be bound by the requirements of this chapter. 
D.  When a parcel of land has been subdivided and a plat thereof submitted bearing the dedication executed by the developers and mortgagors having a recorded interest in the land subdivided, and the approval of the city has been secured and recorded, all streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way and public areas shown on such plat, unless otherwise stated, shall be deemed to have been dedicated to the public for the uses and purposes stated. However, nothing herein shall be construed as creating an obligation upon the city council to perform any act of construction or maintenance within such dedicated areas except where the city council accepts said dedication in writing and where the obligation is voluntarily assumed. 
Section 6.3. - Exemptions. 
    The DSD shall review and determine if the following divisions of land are exempt from the approval processes and platting requirements of this chapter. If the DSD determines that said subdivision is exempt the applicant shall provide a survey or metes and bounds description of the exempt lots to the Volusia County Appraiser's Office and a copy to the DSD. 
A.  The division of any land into a parcel greater than five acres where no new street right-of-way is proposed or required and the parcels front on an existing dedicated public paved street. 
B.  The combination or recombination of previously platted lots or portions of lots where the overall number of lots is not increased, all of the resultant lots meet or exceed the dimensional lot standards of chapter 8 of this code, front on a public paved road and are served by public water and sewer. 
C.  A single lot recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court of the county, or parcel, described by metes and bounds and so recorded before the effective date of this code. 
D.  Any division by inheritance or by partition or other order of court. 
E.  Subdivisions that are platted and recorded in the public records of the County prior to the effective date of this code where the streets have been dedicated to and are maintained by the city, the county or the state. 
F.  Unrecorded subdivisions, the survey of which is dated prior to the effective date of this code where the streets are dedicated to and are maintained by the city, the county or the state. 
G.  Acquisition of property for public purposes. 
H.  The division of any land into no more than five lots with lot and yard dimensions as specified in section 8.6.2 of this Code where no new street right-of-way is proposed or required and the parcels front on an existing dedicated public paved street. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
Section 6.4. - Procedure for subdivision approval. 
6.4.1.  Preapplication conference. Any applicant for review and approval of an exempt minor or major subdivision shall first be required to meet with the planning staff to discuss the proposed subdivision. 
A.  Purpose. The preapplication conference will afford the applicant the opportunity to present the proposal before incurring costs associated with a formal application and will acquaint the applicant with subdivision procedures and requirements and the concerns of the city regarding the property in question. 
B.  Sketch plat. The applicant shall furnish seven copies of a sketch plat of the proposed subdivision to facilitate presentation to and review by the planning staff. The sketch plat should contain the following information at a minimum: 
1.  Scale, north indicator, and name and address of applicant. 
2.  Names and right-of-way dimensions of abutting streets and others within 150 feet. 
3.  Layout and dimensions of original and resulting lots. 
4.  Proposed access and utility easements and right-of-way reservations. 
5.  Zoning classification of the parcel to be subdivided. 
C.  Findings. Based on the information presented by the applicant and review by the planning staff, the DSD shall classify the subdivision as an exempt, minor or major subdivision. Within ten days from the preapplication conference, the DSD shall provide written comments and instructions to the applicant relative to the further documentation and procedures required. 
6.4.2.  Minor subdivisions. Minor subdivisions as defined by this code shall be subject to a review and approval by the TRC as provided for herein. 
A.  Application. An application for minor subdivision approval shall be submitted to the development services department and shall include the following: 
1.  A complete minor subdivision application on an application form provided by the development services department, together with all required exhibits and the subdivision application review fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
2.  Thirteen copies of a plat of the proposed subdivision drawn to a scale of one inch to 50 feet and 13 copies of the required exhibits. Such plat shall contain the following information: 
a.  Scale and north indicator. 
b.  Lot dimensions and legal descriptions. 
c.  Names and dimensions of subdivisions, existing streets, abutting streets and other rights-of-way. 
d.  Easements and right-of-way reservations for utility or access purposes. 
e.  Name, address, telephone and fax number, and email address of applicant. 
f.  Date of plat preparation and identification of preparer, including registration number and certification of accuracy. 
g.  Certification from the county that property taxes due has been paid. 
B.  Review procedure. An application for minor subdivision approval shall be subject to the following review procedure. 
1.  Completeness determination. Within five working days of the receipt of the minor subdivision application, the development services department shall determine whether the application is complete. Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with the deficiencies noted in writing. If the applicant decides to correct the deficiencies, a re-application shall be made to the DSD accompanied by the re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
2.  TRC administrative review. The TRC review shall follow the review procedures as set forth for preliminary plats under section 6.4.3.A.3. of this chapter. 
3.  TRC approval process. After the TRC has considered any applicant, staff and/or public comments, the TRC may approve, approve with conditions or deny the minor subdivision application. The TRC shall have 45 days in which to make its decision. If additional time is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the TRC may table the application until the next meeting, at which time the TRC shall approve, approve with conditions or deny said application. Failure to respond to the outstanding issues shall result in a denied minor subdivision application. If an application is denied, the applicant may appeal said decision as provided in chapter 3 of this code. A minor subdivision application that receives unconditional or conditional approval may be issued a development order in accordance with the provisions of chapter 5 of this code. 
4.  Effect of TRC approval. Upon approval of a minor subdivision application, the city clerk shall transmit a copy of the approved minor subdivision to the county property appraisers office and retain a copy as a part of the official city record. 
6.4.3.  Major subdivisions. Major subdivisions as defined by this code shall be subject to the following requirements: 
A.  Preliminary plat. Submission and approval of a preliminary plat and construction plan shall be a prerequisite to the development of a major subdivision. The preliminary plat shall be submitted before the final plat and shall include the overall preliminary design for the entire area that is proposed to be subdivided. However, the DSD may authorize on a case-by-case basis, the submittal of a preliminary plat and final plat application for consideration for approval at the same time or the submission of a final plat application for approval without a preliminary plat application. 
1.  Application. Application for preliminary plat approval shall be made to the DSD using the application form provided by the development services department for that purpose. The application shall be accompanied by the preliminary plat application review fee as adopted by resolution of the city council and the appropriate number of proposed plans as determined by the development services department. All plans shall be signed and sealed by the project's registered engineer. Preliminary plat applications shall include all required information and exhibits, all applicable standards and specifications of the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual, the City of Orange City Utilities Standard Handbook, and any other applicable requirements of this code. 
2.  Completeness determination. Within five working days of the receipt of the preliminary plat application, the development services department shall determine whether the application is complete. Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with the deficiencies noted in writing. If the applicant decides to correct the deficiencies, a re-application shall be made to the development services department that is accompanied by a re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
3.  TRC administrative review. When a preliminary plat application is determined complete by the DSD, the DSD shall furnish copies to the TRC within five days of making said determination. The TRC shall review the application and provide comments to the DSD within 20 days from the date the TRC receives said copies. The DSD shall submit the TRC comments to the applicant. Based on TRC review, the DSD may advise the applicant to revise the preliminary plat or submit additional information prior to referral of the application to the planning commission. Upon receipt of the DSD comments, the applicant shall have 60 days to make revisions or submit the additional information. If the applicant cannot submit the revisions or additional information within the 60-day period, the applicant may request that the DSD grant an extension for a period not to exceed 30 days. Failure to resubmit all revisions or additional information during the 30-day extension period will require a preliminary plat re-application to the DSD that is accompanied by a preliminary plat re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
4.  Planning commission review and approval process. When the DSD determines that the preliminary plat application has been revised to address all of the TRC comments and that the application complies with all applicable provisions of this code, including the applicable standards and specifications of the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and City of Orange City Utilities Standards Handbook, said application shall be scheduled for the next regular planning commission meeting, but no earlier than two weeks from the date the application was determined complete. The applicant or his representative may appear at the planning commission meeting to discuss the application. The DSD will discuss the TRC comments and recommendations at the planning commission meeting. After the planning commission has considered any applicant, staff and/or public comments, and the TRC recommendations, the commission may recommend approval, approval with conditions or denial of the preliminary plat application. If additional time is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the commission may table the application until the next meeting, at which time the commission shall recommend approval, approval with conditions or denial of said application. The DSD shall forward the commission's recommendation to the city council as specified in section 6.4.4. of this chapter. 
6.4.4.  City council review and approval process. The DSD shall schedule the planning commission's recommendation for city council action within 30 days of the commission's recommendation. After the city council has considered any applicant, staff and/or public comments, and the planning commission recommendations, the city council may approve, approve with conditions or deny the preliminary plat. If additional time for a decision is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the city council may table the application for a period not to exceed 45 days. Failure of the applicant to respond to the outstanding issues shall result in a denied preliminary plat application. A preliminary plat application that receives unconditional or conditional approval may be issued a development order in accordance with the provisions of chapter 5 of this code. 
6.4.5.  Effect of preliminary plat approval. For a preliminary plat that is approved with unconditional approval, the DSD shall issue a preliminary plat development order within five working days of the approval date. For a preliminary plat that is approved with conditions, a revised preliminary plat reflecting said conditions shall be submitted to the DSD within 30 days of the approval date. The revised plat shall be reviewed by the DSD within five working days of resubmittal to determine compliance with said conditions. If the DSD determines that the revised plat is in compliance with said conditions, a preliminary plat development order shall be issued. If the DSD determines that the revised preliminary plat is not in compliance with said conditions, a preliminary plat development order shall not be issued until the applicant revises the plat to meet said conditions. The applicant shall have 60 days from the date of the DSD's determination to submit a revised plat that meets said conditions. If the applicant cannot submit the revised plat that meets said conditions within the 60-day period, the applicant may request that the DSD grant an extension for a period not to exceed 30 days. If the revised plat is either resubmitted but still does not meet said conditions or it is not resubmitted within the 30-day extension period, the preliminary plat conditional approval shall expire. To have the expired application reconsidered, a new preliminary plat application shall be filed with the development services department that is accompanied by a preliminary plat application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. Approval of the preliminary plat development order shall not be construed as authority for filing of the plat with the county clerk or as authority for the sale of lots in reference thereto, but shall authorize the applicant to prepare construction plans, for which development permits may be issued, and prepare the final plat. Preliminary plat approval shall expire one year from the date of preliminary plat approval unless the time is extended by the city council prior to the expiration; otherwise, the applicant must reapply for preliminary plat approval in the manner provided above. 
6.4.6.  Construction plans. Following approval of the preliminary plat, the applicant shall submit to the development services department construction plans for all proposed improvements in or adjoining the subdivision. Said plans shall be prepared by a registered Florida professional engineer. The DSD shall transmit two sets of the complete construction plans and one copy of the approved preliminary plat to the city engineer within five days after receipt. The city engineer shall review the construction plans for conformance to the approved preliminary plat and all applicable design and construction standards, and specifications and shall report findings and recommendations to the DSD in writing within 45 days. The city engineer and DSD may meet with the applicant and/or the engineer of record within this period to discuss the construction plans as submitted. The DSD shall notify the applicant in writing of construction plan approval or disapproval in whole or part within 60 days of receipt from the applicant. Reasons for disapproval shall be stated in writing. Thereafter, the applicant may revise the disapproved construction plans and resubmit within 30 days or appeal the decision of the DSD as provided for by chapter 3 of this code. Upon approval of the construction plans, the applicant shall provide a computer disc in a format acceptable to the DSD. Upon approval the applicant is authorized to apply for development permits related to the installation of all required improvements or having provides guarantees as required by section 6.6 of this chapter, and to proceed with preparation of final plat. 
6.4.7.  Final plat. No lots shall be sold and no street accepted and maintained by the city, nor shall any development permit be issued by the DSD for the construction of any building within such subdivision, unless and until the final plat has been approved by the city council and duly recorded by the county clerk. The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved by the city council and shall incorporate all modifications and revisions specified in the approval of the preliminary plat. 
A.  Application. After preliminary plat approval by the city council and installation of all required improvements or the posting of a surety bond, the subdivider shall, within 12 months, submit the following to the development services department. 
1.  A complete final plat application on an application form provided by the DSD, together with all required exhibits and the final plat application review fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
2.  The original Mylar tracing of the final plat and four reproducible Mylar copies. 
3.  Five printed copies of the final plat with signed certifications and other documents as specified herein and as required for recording by the county clerk. 
B.  Final plat review. The DSD shall transmit documents as specified herein and as required for recording by the county clerk. The original Mylar and one reproducible copy of the final plat to the city engineer within five days after receipt of a complete application. The city engineer shall review the proposed final plat and shall indicate approval by signing the original Mylar and the reproducible copy. The city engineer shall transmit a written report to the DSD within ten days certifying compliance with or noting deviations from the approved preliminary plat and the requirements of this code. If any errors are found in the accuracy of the final plat, the applicant shall be responsible for corrections in the survey or the final plat prior to the city engineer certifying compliance to the city council. 
C.  City council action. If the final plat meets all the requirements of this code, applicable Florida Statutes and complies with the approved preliminary plat, the city council shall approve the final plat and indicate its approval on the original Mylar and on the reproducible copies by signature of the mayor. If the final plat is disapproved by the city council, the reasons for disapproval shall be stated in writing. A copy of such reasons shall be sent by the DSD to the applicant. The applicant may make the necessary changes and resubmit the final plat to the city council through the DSD for review in the manner required above. 
D.  Recording of final plat. Upon approval of the final plat by the city council, the original Mylar of the final plat shall be recorded with the county clerk by the city clerk, with all recording fees paid by the subdivider. The final plat shall be recorded prior to the sale of any lot within the subdivision. Upon recording the approved final plat, a copy of any recorded private covenants or recorded deed restrictions shall be provided by the subdivider for the records of the city clerk. One reproducible 11×17 copy of the final plat shall be retained by the city clerk. The applicant shall also provide the DSD with a computer disc in a format acceptable to the DSD. 
E.  Phased subdivisions. The city council may permit final plat approval of all phases of the subdivision that are to be developed and may require a performance bond or any other surety in such amount as is commensurate with said phases of the plat. Said phases shall contain at least ten percent of the total number of lots in the subdivision. All phases shall receive final approval within one year of preliminary plat approval. Any remaining phases of the approved preliminary plat not receiving final plat approval shall expire, unless such time is extended by the city council. 
    6.4.8. Infill tracts development standards. The purpose of the infill tracts development standards is to allow infill tracts to be divided into a maximum of five lots or less with lot and yard dimensions as specified in section 8.6.2 of this Code, and fronting a public right-of-way through a finger like extension. Said fingerlike portion of the infill lot connecting the main lot body to a public right-of-way shall have a minimum width of 25 feet, a maximum width of 50 feet, and a maximum length of 400 feet. 
A.  Infill tracts shall meet the following requirements. 
1.  Infill tracts shall be processed as a minor subdivision application and comply with all applicable subdivision and site plan regulations of this Code, including meeting all minor subdivision criteria. 
2.  Two internal lots within an infill tract with adjoining fingerlike extensions shall utilize the same driveway, subject to a reciprocal cross access agreement acceptable to the DSD. The combined access to the two inside lots shall have a minimum width of 40 feet, with a driveway at least 15 feet wide. 
3.  All accesses to internal lots shall, at a minimum, be constructed of a stabilized base of clay or in the discretion of the development services director, other suitable material. 
4.  A residential driveway shall be located no closer than five feet to any adjoining property line. Said driveway shall have a minimum ten-foot paved approach apron length, perpendicular and connected to the public street pavement. 
5.  If feasible, the main lot body shall contain a cul-de-sac of sufficient size to accommodate emergency vehicles, and be constructed according to the specifications contained in the design standard manual. 
6.  It is the responsibility of the owner/developer to create the necessary deed restrictions, subject to city attorney approval, as covenants running with the land in order to achieve the following: 
a.  The City of Orange City has no responsibility whatsoever for the maintenance of the fingerlike access to the internal lots. 
b.  To make specific provisions for the ongoing maintenance of said access to be carried out by the owner/developer, their respective heirs, successors and assigns. 
c.  To make specific provisions for the maintenance of common areas, such as stormwater retention. 
d.  The access to the internal lot shall be kept clear for its entire length, at all times, from any obstructions such as fences, planters or decorations. 
e.  The access to the internal lots shall be able to accommodate ingress and egress for emergency vehicles. 
7.  Internal lots shall not be permitted when their effect would be to increase the number of properties requiring direct and individual access connections to major or minor arterials. 
8.  Internal lot driveways, when not combined, shall be separated by at least twice the minimum frontage requirement of its zoning district. 
9.  The lot area occupied by the finger-like extension shall not be counted as part of the required minimum lot area of its zoning district. 
10.  Each internal lot shall possess a minimum of one finger-like extension. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
Section 6.5. - Plat details. 
    Applications for preliminary and final plat approval for all major subdivisions shall be supported by the maps, documents and related information itemized herein. 
6.5.1.  Preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall be drawn clearly and legibly at a scale of at least one inch equals 50 feet, unless otherwise specified by the DSD. The plat shall be drawn by a registered surveyor and/or by a registered professional engineer, showing graphically, or by surveyor or engineering notes, the following information. 
A.  General information. 
1.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
2.  Name, address, telephone and fax number, and email address of the subdivider, agent of the subdivider and engineer of record. 
3.  Name and registration number of surveyor and engineer. 
4.  Date of survey, north point, graphic scale, date of plat drawing and space for revision dates. 
5.  Surveyor's certificate of accuracy. 
6.  Vicinity map showing the relationship between the areas proposed for development, major roads and the surrounding area. 
7.  Boundaries of the tract by bearings, distance, closure and bulkhead lines. 
8.  Legal description of the tract to be subdivided. 
9.  Future land use designations and existing zoning districts on and abutting the tract. 
10.  Names of adjoining subdivisions and/or any property owners, and parcel or lot numbers. 
11.  Existing features within a minimum of 50 feet abutting the proposed subdivision. 
B.  Existing site data. 
1.  City limit lines (if any), existing streets, utilities and easements on and adjacent to the tract, including the location and size of sewers, ditches, culverts, water mains and bridges. 
2.  Other existing improvements, including buildings on land adjacent to the tract. 
3.  Soils survey map of the site. 
4.  Existing natural features, including lakes, marshes or swamps, watercourses, land subject to flooding, wooded areas, general vegetation and other physical conditions affecting the site. 
5.  Existing topography at one foot vertical contour intervals-based on mean sea level data furnished by a professional engineer or surveyor of the site and a minimum of 50 feet of abutting property. 
6.  Existing site vegetation and tree survey, if applicable. 
7.  Identify known plants and animals that inhabit the site and are listed as federal and State endangered, threatened or species of special concern. 
8.  Identify known wildlife corridors for federal and state endangered, threatened or species of special concern. 
9.  Identify known historic and archaeological sites. 
10.  Statement of the proposed arrangements for the maintenance of common open space areas and facilities. 
11.  Tentative construction schedule for the proposed development, including, if applicable, a tentative schedule for phasing the construction. 
12.  A concurrency analysis of the proposed subdivisions impacts on city services and infrastructure as required by chapter 4 of this code. 
C.  Proposed site data. 
1.  Preliminary layout, including streets, alleys and proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses, and all other proposed land uses. 
2.  Block letters and lot numbers. 
3.  Schematic and/or typical layout of buildings on individual lots. 
4.  Minimum building setback lines. 
5.  Proposed method of water supply, sewage disposal, street lighting, and surface drainage with direction of flow and proposed method of stormwater management. 
6.  Required permits from state and local regulatory agencies if any dredging or filling operation is intended in the development of the area. 
7.  Existing and proposed covenants and restrictions. 
8.  Inscription stating "NOT FOR FINAL RECORDING." 
9.  Tree management plan pursuant to the requirements of chapter 11 of this code. 
10.  Proposed street names shall comply with and be approved by the county's E-911 street naming agency. 
11.  Provisions for emergency ingress and egress, such as easements, for subdivisions that have only one entrance. 
12.  Any other information that may be considered necessary by any reviewing agency of the city for full and proper consideration of the proposed subdivision. 
6.5.2.  Construction plans. Plans for the required improvements shall be approved by the city engineer prior to construction and only after approval of the preliminary plat by the city council. Such improvement plans shall show the proposed locations, size, type, grade and general design features of each facility, and shall be based upon reliable field data. 
A.  Improvement construction drawings. Two blueprint drawings shall be submitted to the city engineer, shall be referenced to the name and unit number of the proposed subdivision, and shall show the following information. 
1.  The plan and profile of each proposed street centerline with tentative finish grades indicated. 
2.  A cross section of each proposed street showing the width of pavement, the location and width of sidewalks where required, and the right-of-way. 
3.  Water supply, sewers and stormwater drainage. 
4.  Plans and profiles of all proposed bulkheads and bridges. 
B.  Minimum construction specifications. Minimum construction specifications shall be as specified in the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and the City of Orange City Utilities Standards Handbook. 
6.5.3.  Final plat. The final plat shall be drawn clearly and legibly at a scale of at least one inch equals 50 feet, unless otherwise specified by the DSD. The final plat shall be prepared by a registered surveyor and/or by a registered professional engineer showing graphically, or by surveyor or engineering notes, the information listed below. If more than one sheet is required, an index map relating each sheet to the entire subdivision shall be shown on the first sheet. The final plat shall comply with the requirements of F.S. §§ 177.091 and 177.041, and shall contain the following. 
A.  Name of subdivision. 
B.  Name and address of applicant. 
C.  North point, graphic scale and date. 
D.  Vicinity map showing location and acreage of the subdivision. 
E.  Exact boundary line of the tract determined by field survey, giving distances to the nearest 1/100 foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and closed with an apparent error of closure not to exceed one in 5,000. 
F.  Legal description of the tract. 
G.  Name of owners of adjoining land. 
H.  Locations of streams, lakes, swamps and land subject to flooding. 
I.  Bearing and distance to permanent points of the nearest existing street lines or benchmarks or other permanent monuments (not less than three). 
J.  Municipal and county lines shall be accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines transverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. 
K.  The closest land lot corner shall be accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles. 
L.  Location, dimensions and purposes of any land, reserved or dedicated for public use. 
M.  Exact locations, widths and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the new subdivision. 
N.  Street right-of-way lines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii and lines of tangents. 
O.  Lot lines shall be shown with dimensions to the nearest 1/100 foot and bearings. 
P.  Lots shall be numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically. 
Q.  Accurate location and description of monuments and markers shall be described on the plat. 
R.  Square footage of each lot shall be shown. 
S.  All easements. 
T.  Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land shall be shown by record name, plat book and page number. 
U.  Covenants and restrictions. 
V.  Certifications. The following certifications shall appear on the approved final plat: 
1.  Certification by the surveyor. 
2.  Certification of approval by the city engineer. 
3.  Certification of ownership and dedication of required improvements. 
4.  Acknowledgements. 
5.  Certification of approval by city council. 
Section 6.6. - Installation and guarantee of improvements. 
6.6.1.  Installation of required improvements. Final plats in major subdivisions shall not be approved until the subdivider has installed the required improvements listed in section 6.6.2 of this chapter. In lieu of installing the required improvements prior to final plat approval, the subdivider shall, as part of the final plat approval, provide guarantees in accordance with section 5.1.1 that such improvements will be installed. All improvements shall be installed in conformity with the requirements and standards set forth in this chapter, and all other specifications or requirements of this code, and as specified in the final plat as approved by the city council. All improvement plans and installed improvements shall be inspected and approved by the city engineer as conforming to this chapter and all other requirements of this code. If the developer elects to install improvements after preliminary plat approval and prior to final plat approval, written authorization shall be provided that enables the city engineer or an authorized representative to enter upon the property to be subdivided and make periodic inspections at each stage of development. The engineer of record shall certify that all improvements have been installed in accordance with approved plans and specifications. The developer shall be responsible for the maintenance of the improvements until dedication of the improvements to the city. After the improvements are installed to the satisfaction of the city engineer, said improvements shall be dedicated to the city and maintained by the city. 
6.6.2.  Required improvements. The following improvements are required. 
A.  Survey reference markers. 
B.  Street grading, base preparation and surface course. The number of traffic lanes applicant is required to construct on arterials, collectors and roadways will be dependent on the contributory traffic generated by the proposed development as contained in the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
C.  Storm drainage system. 
D.  Sidewalks installed in accordance with the requirements of the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
E.  Sanitary sewage disposal system (in accordance with city plans), and approved by county health department and the state department of environmental protection if applicable. 
F.  Water supply systems (in accordance with city plans), and approved by the county health department and the state department of environmental protection if applicable. 
G.  Street name markers and traffic control signs constructed of metal with reflective faces. 
H.  Streetlights. 
I.  Bridges. 
6.6.3.  Final acceptance of improvements. Upon completing the installation of all required improvements and prior to final plat approval, the developer shall submit, to the development services department, a request to inspect and have the city engineer approve and accept said improvements. Said request shall be accompanied by as-built plans of all improvements and a maintenance guarantee as set forth in section 5.1.1 to guarantee materials and workmanship for a period of 12 months from the time of dedication to the city. Upon the approval of all required improvements by the city engineer, the city council shall accept said improvements for dedication and maintenance subject to the submittal of a maintenance guarantee as set forth in section 5.1.1. 
6.6.4.  Maintenance guarantee. A maintenance guarantee shall be provided in accordance with section 5.1.1. 
6.6.5.  Guarantee of improvements. The final plat may be recorded prior to the installation of improvements provided said installation is guaranteed, in the form of a performance bond, trust, deed or escrow agreement approved by the city attorney in accordance with section 5.1.1. 
6.6.6.  Use permit required for work within public street right-of-way. Any person, firm or corporation desiring to construct any facility or make any improvements within any public street right-of-way shall secure a use permit from the appropriate governmental agency responsible for the public street. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04; Ord. No. 569 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-17) 
Section 6.7. - Subdivision improvement and design standards. 
6.7.1.  Compliance with standards, inspection and certification of improvements. Approval of the final plat shall be conditioned upon the applicant having installed the required improvements or having provided guarantees, in accordance with section 6.6.5. of this chapter for the installation of said improvements. The city engineer shall be responsible for inspecting and approving all improvement plans and improvements installed in accordance with the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and the City of Orange City Utilities Standards Handbook. The engineer of record shall certify that all improvements have been constructed and installed in accordance with this chapter and all applicable city specifications and standards. 
6.7.2.  Permanent survey reference points. Permanent survey reference monuments shall be installed in all subdivisions in accordance with F.S. ch. 177, and the following requirements. 
A.  Subdivision corner ties. At least one corner of the subdivision shall be designated by course and distance (tie) from a readily discernible reference marker such as a U.S. government marker, section corner or quarter-section corner. When such a monument or station is not available, the tie shall be made to some permanent and readily recognizable landmark or identifiable point, physical object or structure. 
B.  Monuments. At least two monuments shall be installed as control corners within each block within the subdivision. The surveyor shall install additional monuments if required by the city engineer. All monuments shall be constructed of concrete and shall be at least three inches in diameter or square and not less than two feet in length. Each monument shall have embedded in its top or attached by a suitable means a metal plate of noncorrosive material marked plainly with the point, the surveyor's registration number, the month and year it was installed, and the words "Permanent Reference Monument" or the initials "P.R.M." Monuments shall be set in the ground so that the top is flush with the finish grade. 
C.  Property markers. Property markers shall be installed in accordance with F.S. ch. 177. 
D.  Survey accuracy. The allowable angular error of closure and linear error of closure for surveys shall be as follows: 
1.  Angular error of closure shall not exceed 25 seconds times the square root of the number of angles turned. Total error shall be not greater than 40 seconds. 
2.  Linear error of closure shall not exceed one foot per 7,500 feet measured on the perimeter (1:7,500). 
6.7.3.  Streets. Street layout shall be coordinated with the city street system and the following. 
A.  Arterial and collector streets in subdivisions shall be planned in conformity with the city comprehensive plan thoroughfare map. 
B.  The proposed subdivision street layout shall be coordinated with the street system of the surrounding area or with plans for streets in said area on file in the development services department. 
C.  Where, in the opinion of the city council, it is desirable to provide for street access to an adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended by dedication to the boundary of such property and a temporary turnaround provided. 
D.  All streets shall be public unless private streets are approved by the city council upon recommendation of the DSD and approved by the city engineer as part of a cluster subdivision or planned unit development. All streets shall be open to the exterior property line of the subdivision unless they are permanently terminated by a cul-de-sac or an intersection with another street. 
E.  Proposed streets that are obviously in alignment with others existing and named shall bear the assigned names of the existing streets. Street names shall comply with and be approved by the county's E-911 street naming agency. 
F.  All subdivisions shall have at least two separate entrances. Where, in the opinion of the city council, two separate entrances cannot be provided the city council may require an easement for emergency ingress and egress in place of one of the entrances. Primary access to all subdivisions shall be from a street paved to the standards of the Orange City Design Standards Manual. This street, if not already paved, shall be paved by the developer from the subdivision's entrances to the nearest public paved street. The width, grade and construction and material specifications for all streets shall conform to the standards of the Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
G.  All streets shall be paved to the widths as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and be installed by a properly licensed contractor. 
H.  Maximum and minimum centerline and cross section slopes shall be as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
I.  All street rights-of-way shall be graded to their full required width so as to provide adequate shoulders, bike lanes and space for sidewalks. If swale sections are used, rights-of-way may be cleared to the full width. 
J.  Maximum cul-de-sac length and minimum right-of-way and pavement widths shall be as required by the City of Orange City Design Manual. 
K.  Horizontal curves. Where a centerline deflection angle of more than two degrees occurs, a circular curve shall be inserted having a centerline radius of not less than those specified in the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
L.  Intersections. 
1.  When practical, streets shall intersect at an angle of approximately 90 degrees. In no case shall the angles of intersection be less than 60 degrees. 
2.  Street jogs or centerline offsets between streets shall be no less than 150 feet. 
3.  Street curb lines at collector street intersections, minor street intersections, and intersections of collectors and minor streets shall be rounded in accordance with the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. At an angle of intersection of less than 75 degrees, a greater radius may be required by the city engineer. All other streets shall be in accordance with the standards set in the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
4.  Intersections of arterial streets shall not be located closer than 800 feet to each other unless approved by the city council. An arterial street intersecting with another arterial or collector street shall have a minimum increased right-of-way of ten feet on both sides and a minimum paving width of ten feet on both sides for a distance of 150 feet along both intersecting streets to permit proper intersection design. 
5.  Tangents. A tangent of not less than 100 feet in length shall be provided between reverse curves on all arterial and collector streets. 
6.7.4.  Blocks. Blocks shall be designed as follows: 
A.  Block length. Block lengths shall not exceed 1,400 feet or be less than 700 feet. 
B.  Block width. The width of any block shall be of sufficient dimensions to accommodate two tiers of lots except where one tier of lots abuts an area of nonresidential development, an arterial street, a railroad, or a utility right-of-way or on infill fingers. 
6.7.5.  Bridges. Bridges shall be constructed to the width of the connecting roadway pavement, or such additional width as required by the city engineer, with an additional allowance on each side for a pedestrian walk. Bridges extending over waterways shall have a center span and a vertical clearance as required by the city engineer. Bridges shall be designed by a registered Florida professional engineer and conform to applicable AASHTO and ASTM specifications and any federal and state requirements. 
6.7.6.  Drainage easements. 
A.  Drainage easements of a width required for handling and maintaining an adequate storm drainage system shall be provided where required by the city engineer, along waterways, natural watercourses and drainage ways. 
B.  Whenever a subdivision lies wholly or partly in any area for which the city has adopted a drainage plan and is traversed by a natural or designed watercourse for which such plan requires a drainage easement or right-of-way, such easement or right-of-way shall be set forth on the preliminary and final plat and shall be dedicated to the city. 
6.7.7.  Utility easements. Utility easements for both underground and aboveground facilities shall be provided when required. Such easements shall have a minimum width of 15 feet in residential districts and 20 feet in commercial, industrial and mixed use districts and shall normally be laid out on property lines. In all cases, such easements shall be dedicated in perpetuity for their intended use. Easements that are centered along common property lines may be 7.5 feet on each lot within residential districts and ten feet on each lot in commercial, industrial and mixed use districts. 
6.7.8.  Pedestrian easements. Pedestrian easements or walkways shall be provided through the interior of blocks where such easements are required by the city council. Pedestrian easements shall be at least ten feet wide and shall be laid out along side or rear property lines. In all cases, such easements shall be dedicated to the perpetual use of the public. 
6.7.9.  Private easements. Unless approved on the subdivision plat, private easements or reserve strips are prohibited along the perimeter of a subdivision or at the ends of street rights-of-way. 
6.7.10.  Easement maintenance. The city will maintain only those easements, rights-of-way and public sites that it accepts for maintenance. 
6.7.11.  Lots. All lots shall conform to the dimensional yard and building setback requirements of this code. In addition, the following requirements shall apply: 
A.  Width. All lots fronting on a curve shall have a minimum width at the street line of not less than 35 feet. Corner lots shall be 15 percent greater in width than interior lots. 
B.  Depth. Lot depths along arterial streets shall be increased by 50 percent of the depth required by this code or lots shall front on marginal access roads without increased depth. 
C.  Orientation. 
1.  Every lot shall abut a public street that has a minimum right-of-way of at least 50 feet, except for private streets that are approved by the city council. 
2.  Side lot lines shall normally be perpendicular or radial to street right-of-way lines. 
3.  When lots are platted abutting a limited access state or federal highway, ingress and egress shall be limited to the interior subdivision streets. 
6.7.12.  Public sites. 
A.  The subdivider shall dedicate, in accordance with city requirements, suitable sites for public use such as parks, playgrounds and school sites. 
B.  Upon consideration of the particular type of development proposed in the subdivision, and especially in large scale PUDs, the city council may require the dedication or reservation of such other areas or sites of a character, extent and location suitable to meet the needs created by such development for schools, parks, recreation and other similar neighborhood purposes. 
6.7.13.  Utilities. Utilities shall comply with the following: 
A.  Water and sewer. Water and sewer facilities shall conform to the standards, specifications and procedures set forth in City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and the City of Orange City Utilities Standards Handbook and all other applicable state laws, and shall be designed by a registered Florida professional engineer. The cost of installing water and sewer line connections into an existing system shall be borne by the applicant.
