Each lot shall be connected to a main sewer line, where available, by a single lateral. Complete water distribution and sewage collection, treatment and disposal systems shall be installed where required by the Florida Administrative Code in all major subdivisions. If individual sewage facilities are allowed, the developer will be required to deposit in escrow with the city for the purpose of constructing a sewage collection system, the amount of cash equal to 110 percent of the sewage collection system's estimated construction and installation cost. The entire sewage collection system and treatment plant must be engineered and coordinated with the city's overall plan, taking all adjacent areas into consideration, and construction plans prepared. Individual sewage facilities shall be placed in front yards. 
B.  Storm drainage systems. Storm drainage systems shall conform to the stormwater management requirements of this code and be designed by a registered Florida professional engineer. The costs of installing the storm drainage system shall be borne by the applicant. Storm drainage shall be constructed to assure adequate treatment and disposal of drainage water. All storm drainage shall be approved by certification of the engineer of record and the city engineer. 
C.  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be installed in all major and minor subdivisions in accordance with Fire Underwriters requirements. All costs of installing the hydrants shall be borne by the applicant. The location, type and installation of valves and hydrants shall be approved by certification of the engineer of record, the city engineer and the city fire marshal. All fire hydrants shall be within 500 feet of public access. 
D.  Utility sizes. If it is determined that larger utility sizes are necessary and part of a coordinated water and sewer plan, they may be required by the approving body. 
E.  Underground electric power service. In all major and minor subdivisions, all electric power service lines shall be installed underground unless otherwise exempted by the approving body. 
6.7.14.  Control of floodplain areas and unsafe land. The approving body shall, after considering the recommendation of the city engineer and the DSD, and if deemed necessary for the health, safety and welfare of the present and future population of the city and necessary to the conservation of the general environment, restrict subdivision development of any property that lies within the 100-year floodplain of any river, lake, stream or other drainage course. 
A.  Floodplain areas. Where lands are or have been subject to periodic flooding and minimum centerline roadway elevations have not been established by the city council, interim minimum centerline roadway elevations shall be established by the following method. The engineer of record shall establish floodplain and design flood conditions that are acceptable to the city engineer. Minimum centerline roadway and floor elevations shall be established as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
B.  Unsafe land. The approving body may require the designation of a building restriction line, in accordance with section 6.7.14.C. of this chapter, any land that is found to be unsafe for development use by reason of flooding, erosive stream action, or unstabilized slope or fill, or otherwise located so that safe, healthful development cannot be maintained on the land. 
C.  Designation of building restriction line. A building restriction line shall be used to designate floodplain or unsafe building areas in all cases where the areas are not shown on the preliminary and final plats as rights-of-way or easements in accordance with this chapter. The approving body may permit floodplain areas or unsafe land to be platted as a part of a lot in which there is sufficient safe ground to erect a building or dwelling within the required setbacks of the zoning district. In the event that such land is platted as a part of a buildable lot, there shall be placed on such platted lot a building restriction line, which shall be located so as to provide at least a 50-foot setback between any buildings and the unsafe or floodplain areas or a greater setback where necessary to provide positive drainage between the building and unsafe area. 
D.  Removal of building restriction line. Where it is deemed by the approving body that unsafe land or floodplain areas have, by subsequent change in conditions, become safe for building, the building restriction line may be reset in accordance with the change in condition by the recording of a new plat approved in accordance with these regulations. 
E.  Denial of development permit. No development permit shall be issued within any building restriction line or in other areas within a floodplain or on unsafe land for any structure or addition to existing structures except for fences, walls, public utilities and other such structures approved by the approving body as is reasonable and not contrary to the safety, health and welfare of the public. 
Section 6.8. - Modifications and requirements above minimum. 
    When, in the judgment of the approving body, strict application of the requirements of chapter 6 would produce in an inequitable or unreasonable result, stifle innovative or creative design, or create undue hardship when applied to a specific subdivision, the approving body may modify such requirements to the extent necessary to achieve equity or reasonableness, or relieve the undue hardship. Said modifications shall not be inconsistent with the comprehensive plan; create nonconforming uses, lots or structures; be contrary to requirements of law or the general policies of this code. Nor shall any such modification applied to one subdivision establish precedent with regard to any other subdivision. Application for such modification shall be submitted by the applicant in writing with the plat application. If said modification is granted, the applicant shall provide a revised plat to the DSD with notification of said modification. Additionally, the approving body may, on a case-by-case basis, request more than minimum requirements as conditions for plat application approval where such additional requirements are deemed in the public interest. 
Section 6.9. - Plat vacation. 
6.9.1.  Conversion of lots to acreage. The owner of any land subdivided into lots may file to record a plat for the purpose of showing such land as acreage. Such plat and the procedure in connection therewith shall conform to the requirements of this chapter, regulations adopted pursuant thereto and F.S. ch. 177, with the following exceptions: 
A.  No survey or certificate of any surveyor or engineer shall be required. However, the city council may require a survey of the exterior boundaries of the land and the placing of suitable monuments along such boundaries if it finds that the last preceding survey of record is faulty, inadequate or that insufficient monuments are in position along such boundaries. 
B.  No improvements shall be required except such as may be necessary to provide equivalent access, as provided hereafter in this section. 
C.  No findings need be made as to the suitability of the land or as to the provision of public facilities and services for it. 
6.9.2.  City council action. The city council may order the vacation and reversion to acreage of all or any part of a subdivision within its jurisdiction, including the vacation of streets or other parcels of land dedicated for public purposes or any of such streets or other parcels by adoption of an ordinance, when: 
A.  The plat of the subdivision was recorded as provided by law not less than five years before the date of such action; and 
B.  In the subdivision or part thereof, not more than ten percent of the total subdivision area has been sold as lots by the original subdivider or successors in title. 
6.9.3.  City council finding. Such action shall be based on a finding by the city council for the approval of subdivision plats that the proposed vacation and reversion to acreage of subdivided land conforms to the comprehensive plan and that the public health, safety, economy, comfort, order, convenience and welfare will be promoted thereby. Before acting on the proposal for vacation and reversion of subdivided land to acreage, the city council shall conduct a public hearing with due public notice. 
Section 6.10. - Penalties and prohibitions. 
6.10.1.  Penalties for transferring lots in unapproved subdivisions. It shall be unlawful for anyone to transfer, sell, agree to sell or negotiate to sell land by reference to, exhibition of or other use of a sketch plat, drawing and/or unrecorded plat as a depiction of a subdivision of land without having submitted a subdivision application for approval as required by this chapter and if applicable without having recorded the approved subdivision plat as required by this code. If such unlawful use be made of an unrecorded plat and/or depict or drawing of a division of land before it is properly reviewed, approved and recorded if applicable, the owner or agent of the owner of such land shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be punishable as provided by law. The city council, through its city attorney, may enjoin such transfer, sale or agreement. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall not impair the title of land so transferred or affect the validity of the title conveyed. However, a purchaser of land sold in violation of this section shall, within one year from the date of purchase thereof, be entitled to bring an appropriate action to void such sale or to bring action against the seller for any damages suffered as a result of the seller's unlawful act, or both. This section shall not apply to those land divisions that the DSD has determined exempt pursuant to section 6.3 of this chapter. 
6.10.2.  Erection of buildings adjacent to unapproved streets. No building shall be erected on a lot or parcel of land within the city, nor shall any building permit be issued therefore, unless the street giving access to the lot or parcel on which such building is proposed has been accepted and opened as a public street; has otherwise received the legal status of a public street; has been accepted by the city council and is shown on a recorded subdivision plat; or is an approved private street dedicated for the use of certain lots or parcels but not accepted for maintenance by the council or available for use by the public. This section shall not apply to those lands divisions that the DSD has determined exempt pursuant to section 6.3 of this chapter. 
Section 6.11. - Appeals. 
A.  Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, any aggrieved person may appeal a decision of a city official, the TRC, or city council as provided by chapter 3 of this code. 
CHAPTER 7. - SITE PLAN REVIEW 

Section 7.1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to set forth a uniform site plan application review and approval process, identify information that shall be submitted as part of the site Plan application, and ensure that development is not only compatible with the surrounding area but also with the project site's topography, trees and natural features and conditions. 
Section 7.2. - Applicability. 
    Unless otherwise exempted by this code, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect, or alter a building or structure or to develop, change, or improve land for which a site plan is required except in accordance with an approved site plan development order for which a development permit has been issued. Site plan review and approval shall be required for all but the following types of development activity and use. 
A.  The construction, alteration or enlargement of a one-or two-family dwelling unit. 
B.  Accessory uses and structures, including garage apartments, guest cottages and home occupations that meet the definitions and conditions of this code, except those that exceed the thresholds established in section 7.2.C. of this chapter. 
C.  One-time additions and improvements to existing parcels where such activity does not constitute a new use and provided that additions to nonresidential buildings are less than 1,000 square feet in floor area, are less than 25 percent of the existing floor area, require less than five new off-street parking spaces, and do not expand existing permitted outdoor storage and display areas by more than 25 percent. 
D.  Change from one permitted use to another permitted use in a particular zoning district that meets all applicable requirements of this code and provided that the change of use does not exceed the thresholds for new construction and additional off-street parking established in section 7.2.C. of this chapter. 
Section 7.3. - Application requirements, information and exhibits. 
7.3.1.  Sketch plan. Prior to submittal of a site plan application, the applicant shall submit a sketch plan of the proposed development to the development services department as a basis for informal discussion of potential issues regarding the development proposal and to verify the steps necessary for site plan application review and approval process. The sketch plan shall include the following exhibits. 
A.  Statement of ownership of the proposed development. The names, addresses, telephone and fax numbers, and email addresses of the owner, developer, the project's engineers, architects, landscape architects, planners and surveyor. 
B.  Parcel's legal description and tax parcel number. 
C.  Current comprehensive plan future land use designation and zoning district for both the parcel and surrounding parcels. 
D.  Schematic representation of the proposed use, including building size, shape and location on the site. 
E.  Schematic representation of vehicular circulation within the site, including driveways, parking area and off street loading areas. 
F.  Schematic representation of points of connection to the public right-of-way. 
The DSD will meet with the applicant to discuss the project and will inform the applicant at that time of the issues, concerns and requirements to be addressed in the application for site plan approval. Comments made at this stage in the process are intended to provide guidance and are nonbonding on the required review of the site plan. 
7.3.2.  Site plan application information, exhibits and submittal requirements. After the completion of the sketch plan review as required by section 7.3.1. of this chapter, the applicant shall submit a site plan application that provides the following information and exhibits, unless waived by the DSD. 
A.  General information. 
1.  Name of project. 
2.  Statement of the parcel's intended use. 
3.  Legal description, tax parcel number, size of parcel in acres or square feet and linear dimensions of the parcel. 
4.  Name, address, telephone and fax numbers, and email address of the parcel's owner or owners of record. 
5.  Name, address, telephone and fax numbers, and email address of the applicant and the firm represented. 
6.  Name, address, signature, and registration number of the project engineer, architect, landscape architect and surveyor. 
7.  Vicinity map, at a scale of not less than one inch equals 2,000 feet, showing the relationship of the proposed development to the surrounding streets and thoroughfares. 
8.  A survey of the property, prepared by a registered surveyor, showing the boundaries, acreage and linear dimensions of the site, any existing streets, structures, watercourses, waterbodies, swamps and wetlands, easements and section lines. 
9.  A signed and sealed site plan containing the title of the project, its date, scale no smaller than one inch equals 50 feet, a north arrow and illustrating the information as required hereafter. Said plan shall be submitted in both hard copy and computer compact disk format acceptable to the DSD. 
B.  Existing conditions and improvements. 
1.  Current comprehensive plan future land use designation and current zoning for the project parcel and adjoining parcels. 
2.  Existing and proposed topography at one-foot contour intervals. 
3.  All existing and proposed building restriction lines (i.e., highway setback lines, easements, covenants, rights-of-way, building setback lines and any other building restriction lines as listed in the site plan review checklist, even if more restrictive than those specified by chapter 8 of this code). 
4.  Existing site vegetation and tree survey if applicable. 
5.  A certification of known plants and animals that inhabit the site that are listed as Federal and State endangered, threatened or species of special concern. 
6.  Identify known wildlife corridors for federal and state endangered, threatened or species of special concern. 
7.  Identify known historic and archaeological sites. 
8.  Soils. 
a.  A soil classification map as an overlay for comparison with proposed development activities shall be provided and indicate soil classifications on the site plan as identified by the United States Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Service. An applicant may challenge this designation by securing competent expert evaluation; at the applicant's own expense, demonstrating that the identified soils are not classified correctly. If said determination is concurred with by the city engineer, the soils shall be correctly identified for the purpose of this code. 
b.  A soil analysis prepared by a registered engineer shall be furnished by the applicant. 
9.  Limits of floodplain. Indicate the Federal Flood Insurance Administration 100-year flood plain elevation on the site plan if available. If none is available, a registered engineer shall provide a certified 100-year flood elevation. 
10.  The following existing improvements that are on-site, adjacent to the site, or across or opposite any public rights-of-way shall be dimensionally illustrated on the site plan. 
a.  Driveways and median cuts within 150 feet of the project in both directions on both sides of the street right-of-way. 
b.  Sidewalks, streets, alleys and easements (note widths and type). 
c.  Drainage systems, to include natural and structural (size and materials, invert elevation) including all offsite areas draining to the site. 
d.  Size and location of nearest water mains, valves and fire hydrants. 
e.  Sanitary sewer systems (size, invert elevation, etc. to be included). 
f.  Gas, power, telephone lines, and utility and light poles, where applicable. 
C.  Provide the following information for all proposed and planned improvements. 
1.  Building and structures. 
a.  Intended use, location, building separation, exterior openings and dimensions of the building footprint. 
b.  Number of stories. 
c.  Height of building. 
d.  Number of dwelling units and density for multifamily site plans. 
e.  Percentage of building lot coverage and floor area ratio. 
f.  Type of construction. 
g.  Architectural drawings, elevations and applicable architectural design standards as required by chapter 10 of this code prepared by a licensed architect. 
h.  Location and plans for any outdoor storage areas. 
i.  Location of bus stop areas. 
j.  Location of bicycle rack areas. 
k.  Projected number of employees and number of company vehicles kept at the site. 
l.  For restaurants, entertainment or similar establishments, houses of worship, funeral homes or other places of assembly show number of seats and occupancy load. 
m.  Design of proposed sign(s) and sign location, size and setbacks. 
2.  Streets, sidewalks, driveways, parking areas and off-street loading and unloading spaces. 
a.  Engineering plan specifications and cross-sections for streets, sidewalks, driveways, vehicular and bicycle parking areas as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
b.  Number, location and dimensions of all off-street parking spaces and how the number was calculated as required by section 8.7.7. of this code. 
c.  Number and location of handicapped spaces. 
d.  Number, location and dimensions of all off-street loading and unloading spaces and how the number was calculated as required by section 8.7.7. of this code. 
e.  Number of square feet of paved parking and driveway area. 
f.  Fire lanes and/or other areas for emergency vehicles including fire fighting vehicles and provisions for ingress and egress for said vehicles. 
g.  Location of proposed driveway and median cut. 
h.  Internal traffic circulation plan, including directional arrows and signs to direct traffic flow. 
i.  Location of traffic control signs and signalization devices. 
j.  Location of sidewalks. 
k.  Coordination of walkways, bikeways, driveways etc., with facilities in adjacent developments. 
l.  All proposed street rights-of-way and alleys. 
m.  Extension or construction of service roads and on-site access must be shown where applicable. 
n.  Square footage of each landscape island. 
3.  Drainage. 
a.  Computation of pervious and impervious area, in square footage and percentage. 
b.  Direction of drainage flows and nature of retention facilities both on-and offsite, if applicable. 
c.  Engineering plans and specifications for the collection and treatment of storm drainage as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual, including a description of the preservation of any natural features, such as lakes, streams, other natural features and other information required by the city engineer. 
d.  If applicable, exfiltration systems shall be designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the Saint Johns River Water Management District's standards. 
4.  Dredge and fill. If any dredging or filling operation is planned for the project, the engineer of record shall consult with the city engineer to ensure conformity with dredge and fill requirements. 
5.  Erosion control. Provisions for the adequate control of erosion and sediment as required by the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual, indicating the location and description of the methods to be used during and after all phases of clearing, grading and construction. 
6.  Proposed water and sewer facilities. 
a.  Water. Size, material, and location of water mains, valves and fire hydrants, including engineering plans and specifications as required by the City of Orange City Utilities Standard Handbook. Also the date potable water facilities are needed to serve the proposed development and a commitment from Volusia County to serve said development, if applicable, demonstrating that adequate capacity shall be available to service the proposed development at the time of impact as required in chapter 4 of this code. 
b.  Sanitary sewer systems. Size, material, inverts of manholes, slope of the sewer and location of lines, including engineering plans and specifications as required by the Orange City Utilities Standard Handbook. Also the date sanitary sewer facilities are needed to serve the proposed development and a commitment from Volusia County to serve said development, if applicable, demonstrating that adequate capacity shall be available to service the proposed development at the time of impact as required in chapter 4 of this code. 
7.  Solid waste. Location and access provisions for refuse service, including pad, screening, fencing and landscaping. 
8.  Landscaping, recreation and open space. 
a.  Landscaping and underground irrigation system plan signed and sealed by a registered landscape architect including size, type and location of all landscaping, screens, walls, fences, and buffers. 
b.  Indication of existing native vegetation that will be preserved. 
c.  Tree planting and protection plan. 
d.  Recreation and open space areas, as applicable. 
e.  Statement of the provision of maintenance of landscaping. 
f.  Statement of the proposed arrangements for the maintenance of common open space areas and facilities. 
9.  Tentative construction schedule for the proposed development, including if applicable, a tentative schedule for the phasing construction. 
10.  A concurrency analysis as required by chapter 4 of this code of the project's impacts on city services and infrastructure. 
Section 7.4. - Development entrance and paved street requirements. 
    All proposed developments that require site plan approval, except for utilities, essential services and communication towers, shall front on a paved street and have at least two separate entrances. Where, in the opinion of the approving body, two separate entrances cannot be provided the approving body may require an easement for emergency ingress and egress in place of one of the entrances. Primary access to all proposed developments shall be from a street paved to the standards of the Orange City Design Standards Manual. This street, if not already paved, shall be paved by the developer from the development's entrances to the nearest public paved street. The width, grade, construction and material specifications for all streets shall conform to the standards of the Orange City Design Standards Manual. 
Section 7.5. - Site plan application review and approval processes. 
7.5.1.  TRC administrative review and approval process. If the proposed site plan application is for a development of 20 dwelling units or less, or 20,000 gross square feet or less of nonresidential floor area, said application shall be subject to the following review and approval process. 
A.  Application for site plan approval shall be made to the development services department using the application form provided by the development services department for that purpose. The application shall be accompanied by the site plan application review fee as adopted by resolution of the city council and the appropriate number of proposed plans as determined by the DSD. All plans shall be signed and sealed by the project's registered engineer, architect and landscape architect. Site plan applications shall be prepared to include all information and exhibits required by section 7.3.2. of this chapter, any other items agreed upon during the pre-application conference, all applicable standards and specifications of the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and any other applicable requirements of this code. 
B.  Within five working days of the receipt of the site plan application, the DSD shall determine whether the application is complete. Incomplete applications shall be returned to the applicant with the deficiencies noted in writing. If the applicant decides to correct the deficiencies, a re-application shall be made to the DSD that is accompanied by a re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
C.  When a site plan application is determined complete, the DSD shall furnish copies to the TRC for review and schedule a TRC meeting no later than 40 days from the date of said determination. The applicant or applicant's representative may meet with the TRC. The TRC shall approve, approve with conditions or deny the site plan application. The DSD shall inform the applicant, in writing, of the TRC decision within five working days of the TRC making its decision on said application. If additional time is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the TRC may table the application for a period not to exceed 20 days. Once the outstanding issues are addressed, the DSD shall inform the applicant, in writing, of the TRC decision within five working days from the date of the TRC decision. Failure to respond to the outstanding issues shall result in a denied site plan application. A site plan application that receives unconditional or conditional approval may be issued a development order in accordance with the provisions of section 7.5 of this chapter. 
7.5.2.  Planning commission review and approval process. If the proposed site plan application is for a development of more than 20 dwelling units or more than 20,000 gross square feet of nonresidential floor area, said application will be subject to the following review and approval process. 
A.  Application for site plan approval shall be made following the procedures as specified in section 7.4.1.A. and B. 
B.  When a site plan application is determined complete by the DSD, the DSD shall furnish copies to the TRC within five days of making said determination. The TRC shall review the site plan and provide comments to the DSD within 20 days of the date the TRC received the copies. The DSD shall submit the TRC comments to the applicant. 
C.  Based on TRC review, the DSD may advise the applicant to revise the site plan or submit additional information prior to referral of the application to the planning commission. The applicant shall have 60 days to make revisions or submit the additional information requested by the DSD. If the applicant cannot submit the revisions or additional information within the 60-day period, the applicant may request that the DSD grant an extension for a period not to exceed 30 days. Failure to resubmit all revisions or additional information during the 30 day extension period will require a site plan re-application to the development services department that is accompanied by a site plan re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
D.  When the DSD determines that the site plan application has been revised to address all of the TRC comments and that the application complies with all applicable provisions of this code, including the applicable standards and specifications of the City of Orange City Design Standards Manual and the City of Orange City Utilities Standards Handbook, said application shall be scheduled for the next regular planning commission meeting, but no earlier than two weeks from the date the application was determined complete. The applicant or his representative may appear at the planning commission meeting to discuss the application. The DSD will discuss the TRC comments and recommendations at that time. 
E.  After the planning commission has considered any applicant, staff and/or public comments, and the TRC recommendations, the commission may approve, approve with conditions or deny the site plan application. If additional time is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the commission may table the application until there next meeting at which time the commission shall approve, approve with conditions or deny said application. Failure to respond to the outstanding issues shall result in a denied site plan application. A site plan application that receives unconditional or conditional approval may be issued a development order in accordance with the provisions of section 7.5 of this chapter. 
7.5.3.  City council review and approval process. If the proposed site plan application is for a development more than five acres in land area, said application shall be subject to the following review and approval process. 
A.  The site plan application shall be processed and reviewed as set forth in section 7.5.2.A.-E. of this chapter, except that the planning commission's final decision will be in the form of a recommendation to the city council for final action. The DSD shall schedule the planning commission's recommendation for city council action within 30 days of the commission's recommendation. 
B.  After the city council has considered any applicant, staff and/or public comments and the planning commission recommendations; the city council may approve, approve with conditions, or deny the site plan. If additional time for a decision is needed to allow for the resolution of outstanding issues, the city council may table the application for a period not to exceed 45 days. Failure to respond to the outstanding issues shall result in a denied site plan application. A site plan application that receives unconditional or conditional approval may be issued a development order in accordance with the provisions of section 7.5 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
Section 7.7. - Effect of site plan approvals. 
    For a site plan that is approved with unconditional approval, the DSD shall issue a site plan development order within five working days of the approval date. For a site plan that is approved with conditions, a revised site plan reflecting said conditions shall be submitted to the DSD within 30 days of the approval date. The revised plan shall be reviewed by the DSD within five working days of resubmittal to determine compliance with said conditions. If the DSD determines that the revised site plan is in compliance with said conditions, a site plan development order shall be issued. If the DSD determines that the revised site plan is not in compliance with said conditions, a site plan development order shall not be issued until the applicant revises the site plan to meet said conditions. The applicant shall have 60 days from the date of the DSD's determination to submit a revised site plan that meets said conditions. If the applicant cannot submit the revised site plan that meets said conditions within the 60-day period; the applicant may request that the DSD grant an extension for a period not to exceed 30 days. If the revised site plan is either resubmitted but still does not meet said conditions or it is not resubmitted within the 30 day extension period, the site plan conditional approval shall expire. To have the expired application reconsidered, a new site plan application shall be filed with the development services department that is accompanied by a site plan re-application fee as adopted by resolution of the city council. Upon approval of a site plan and the completion of any site plan revisions as required to meet any applicable approved conditions, the applicant shall furnish the DSD with a site plan in both hard copy drawing and a computer compact disk format acceptable to the DSD. 
Section 7.8. - Appeals. 
    An appeal of a TRC, planning commission or city council decision shall be filed in the manner provided for by chapter 3 of this code. 
Section 7.9. - Development agreement. 
    If determined necessary by the DSD to secure the future performance of any conditions imposed by the city or representations made by the applicant, an executed development agreement in a form acceptable to the city attorney may be required. In such an event, the developer shall be required to pay all costs involved in the preparation and recording of such agreement. 
Section 7.10. - Additional required submittals only where facilities are dedicated to the public. 
    The approval of the site plan development order shall, where facilities are dedicated to the city, be made only pursuant to certification of adequacy of the following list of required submittals by the city engineer and/or city attorney, as appropriate. 
7.10.1.  Improvement guarantee. The approval of any site plan development order shall be subject to the applicant guaranteeing the installation and maintenance of the required improvements, where these facilities are to be conveyed or dedicated to the city, by filing a performance guarantee in accordance with section 5.1.1. 
7.10.2.  Title certificate. A certificate of ownership in a form approved by the city attorney signed by a licensed attorney-at-law or an abstract company licensed to do business in the state shall be required when property is conveyed to the city. The certificate shall include the following. 
A.  The parties executing the site plan application are owners of the land embraced by the parcel. 
B.  All mortgages, liens or other encumbrances. 
C.  That all taxes and assessments are paid to date. 
D.  Correct description of the parcel. 
E.  No conflicting rights-of-way, easements or site plans exist. 
7.10.3.  Construction costs. Itemized costs shall be submitted concurrently with all required bonds for review by the city engineer. An engineer's cost estimate or the accepted contractor's bid shall be submitted for performance bond review. A corrected contractor's bid reflecting any additional cost increases shall be required for the review of maintenance bonds. All cost documents shall be signed and sealed where appropriate. 
( Ord. No. 569 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-17) 
Section 7.11. - Site plan development order modification, expiration, extension and enforcement. 
    Following approval of the site plan development order, said order shall be subject to the modification, expiration, extension and enforcement provisions as provided for in chapter 5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 244, § 2, 5-10-05; Ord. No. 261, § 1, 1-24-06) 
Section 7.12. - Modifications and requirements above minimum. 
    When, in the judgment of the site plan application approving body (i.e. TRC, planning commission or city council), strict application of the requirements of chapter 7 would produce an inequitable or unreasonable result, stifle innovative or creative design, or create undue hardship when applied to a specific project or development, the approving body may modify such requirements to the extent necessary to achieve equity or reasonableness or relieve the undue hardship. Said modifications that are granted shall not be inconsistent with the comprehensive plan; create nonconforming uses, lots or structures; be contrary to requirements of law or the general policies of this code; nor shall any such modification as applied to one development establish precedent with regard to another development subject to review. Application for such modification shall be submitted by the applicant in writing with the site plan application. If said modification is granted the applicant shall provide a revised site plan to the DSD with notations of said modification. Additionally the approving body may, on a case-by-case basis, request more than minimum requirements related to access, off-street parking, landscaping, and the like as conditions for final site plan application approval where such additional requirements are deemed in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
CHAPTER 8. - ZONING REGULATIONS 

Section 8.1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of these regulations is to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to promote public health, safety, morals and the general welfare, to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to retain productive agriculture areas and to facilitate the provision of essential government services such as transportation, water, sewage disposal, schools and parks. 
Section 8.2. - Nonconforming provisions. 
8.2.1.  Conformance required. No parcel or structure shall be used and no structure shall be erected, constructed or altered which is not in conformance with the applicable use, lot, yard, height, and other regulations in this chapter, except as may be provided herein. 
8.2.2.  Nonconforming uses. Any principal or accessory use existing on the effective date of this code or amendment thereto but not permitted thereafter shall be deemed a nonconforming use. Such nonconforming use may continue in use provided that: 
A.  The use is not enlarged, increased or extended to be greater than existed on the effective date of this code or amendment, which caused its nonconformance. 
B.  No additional structure is erected or constructed in connection with such use, except that nothing in this code shall prevent the repair or rehabilitation of a building or part thereof, provided, however, that building height and floor area are not increased. 
C.  A use, which shall have been abandoned or ceased in operation for at least 12 months, shall not be reestablished as a nonconforming use. 
8.2.3.  Nonconforming lots. In any zoning district, principal and accessory structures otherwise authorized under this chapter may be erected or constructed on any single nonconforming lot, which existed, separate and apart from other adjoining lots owned by the same person, on the effective date of adoption or amendment of this code, if all zoning district requirements other than lot area or width are met. If two or more lots and/or combinations of lots and/or portions of lots that abut in single ownership existed on the effective date of adoption or amendment of this code, or if such lots and/or portions thereof are subsequently combined in single ownership with other adjoining lots, and if all or part of the lots do not meet the requirements established for lot width or lot area, then the lands involved shall be considered to be an undivided lot for the purposes of this code. No portion of said undivided lot shall be sold or subdivided in a manner, which does not comply with the lot width, or lot area requirements established within this chapter. Provided, however, a nonconforming lot may be increased in size even if such increase does not allow the lot to meet the minimum lot width and lot area requirements established by this chapter. Provided further, the adjoining lot or lots, from which the land is removed to create the increase to the subject lot, does not become nonconforming or does not increase in nonconformity. Any relief, which may be granted under this section, shall be considered a variance. After the effective date of adoption or amendment of this code, no new subdivision shall be permitted which creates a lot width or area below the requirements required by this chapter. Additionally, nonconforming lots under single ownership that are vacant or developed, may be used provided that the use is a conforming use and the minimum lot width is 50 feet or greater. 
8.2.4.  Nonconforming structures. Any structure existing on the effective date of this code or amendment thereto which thereafter is not in conformance with the yard, height and other requirements of this code shall be deemed a nonconforming structure. Such nonconforming structure may continue in use, provided that: 
A.  It is not enlarged, altered or extended in any way, which increases its nonconformity (it may be altered to decrease its nonconformity, however). 
B.  If it is damaged in excess of 50 percent of its then-assessed value, any reconstruction shall comply with this code. 
C.  If it is moved for any reason, or for any distance, it shall thereafter conform to this code. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
Section 8.3. - Establishment of zoning districts. 
    The incorporated area of Orange City is hereby divided into the zoning districts listed below and in the manner shown on the OZM. That map and the explanatory material contained on its face are incorporated in this code by reference. 
RR Rural residential. 
R-1 Low density residential. 
R-2 Medium density residential. 
R-3 High density residential. 
MH-1 Mobile home park. 
OT Office transitional. 
MX-1 Mixed use, urban. 
MX-2 Mixed use, suburban. 
CG-1 General commercial, restricted. 
CG-2 General commercial. 
CR Commercial Recreation 
I-1 Light industrial. 
I-2 Heavy industrial. 
PUD Planned unit development. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04; Ord. No. 454, § 1(Exh. A), 5-24-11) 
Section 8.4. - OZM. 
8.4.1.  Identification of official zoning map (OZM). The OZM as prepared by the development services department shall be entrusted to the custody of the city clerk and shall be located in the office of the city clerk. It shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, attested by the city clerk, and shall bear the city seal under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the OZM referred to in chapter 8 of this Code. 
8.4.2.  Amendments. Adopted amendments to the OZM shall be promptly noted on the true copy of the OZM by inserting the ordinance number and date of adoption on or near the affected lot. 
8.4.3.  Retention of earlier zoning maps. All zoning maps and regulations or remaining portions thereof, which have official force and effect in the city prior to the effective date of this code, shall be retained as public records. 
8.4.4.  Replacement of OZM. If the OZM is damaged, destroyed, lost or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of changes and additions, the city council may adopt, after due public notice, an updated OZM which will supersede the prior OZM. The updated OZM may correct drafting or other errors or omissions in the prior OZM, but no such corrections shall have the effect of amending the original OZM or any subsequent amendment thereof. The updated OZM shall be identified in the same manner as the original OZM, except that the certificates shall state: "This is to certify that this OZM supersedes and replaces the OZM adopted on ________, as part of this code dated ________. Unless the prior OZM has been lost or has been totally destroyed, the prior map or any significant parts thereof remaining shall be preserved, together with all available records pertaining to its adoption or amendment. 
Section 8.5. - Interpretation of zoning district boundaries. 
    The following rules of interpretation shall be used to locate the zoning district boundaries shown on the OZM: 
8.5.1.  Boundaries following streets. Boundaries following, or approximately following, the centerlines of streets shall be construed to follow those centerlines. If a street is vacated, the district boundary shall be construed to remain in its location, except when ownership of the vacated street is divided other than at the center; in which case, the boundary shall be construed to move with the ownership. 
8.5.2.  Boundaries following lot lines. Boundaries following, or approximately following, lot lines shall be construed to follow those lot lines. 
8.5.3.  Boundaries following county and city limits. Boundaries following, or approximately following, county and City limits shall be construed to follow those county and city limits. 
8.5.4.  Boundaries following water bodies. Boundaries following, or approximately following, the mean high-water line of a water body shall be construed to follow and move with that mean high-water line. Boundaries following, or approximately following, the centerlines of bodies of water shall be construed to follow and move with those centerlines. 
8.5.5.  Boundaries entering any body of water. Boundaries entering any body of water, but not continuing to intersect with other zoning boundaries, shall be construed to extend in the same direction in which they entered the body of water, until they intersect with other zoning boundaries. 
8.5.6.  Increase of incorporated area by municipal annexation. If city limits change through annexation, no use or uses may be made of the property annexed, other than that allowed under Volusia County development and zoning standards, until an appropriate city zoning district has been assigned for the property. 
8.5.7.  Boundaries parallel to or extensions of above features. Boundaries apparently parallel to or extensions of the features indicated in sections 8.5.1 through 8.5.6 shall be construed to be parallel to or extensions of those features, as the case may be. 
8.5.8.  Other cases. Boundaries splitting existing lots in subdivisions and any other boundaries not determined by the above rules shall be determined by reference to the expressed distances on or the scale of the OZM. In unsubdivided property or where a zoning district boundary divides a lot, the location of such boundary, unless the same is indicated by dimensions, shall be determined by the use of the scale appearing on the original map. Where a zoning district boundary divides a lot, the zoning district of the greater portion shall prevail throughout the lot. 
(Ord. No. 210, Exh. A, 8-24-04) 
Section 8.6. - District regulations. 
8.6.1.  Schedule of zoning districts permitted and conditional uses. (See attachment [table] at end of chapter.) 
8.6.2.  Schedule of lot and building requirements. (See attachment [table] at end of chapter.) 
8.6.3.  Rural residential (RR). 
A.  Intent. The RR district provides for low density residential development at densities up to one unit per 21/2 acres consistent with the RL future land use designation of the comprehensive plan. 
B.  Permitted principal uses. Permitted principle uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
C.  Accessory uses and structures. Accessory uses and structures are limited to those uses and structures that meet the criteria of section 8.7.1. of this chapter. 
D.  Conditional uses. Conditional uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
E.  Lot and building requirements. Standards relating to lot and yard dimensions, size and placement of buildings on a lot, and density or intensity of developments in the RR district shall be as specified in section 8.6.2. of this chapter. 
F.  Off-street parking and loading requirements. Standards for off-street parking and loading and unloading shall be as specified in section 8.7.7. of this chapter. 
G.  Sign regulations. Standards as to the type, size and placement of signs shall be as specified in chapter 9 of this code. 
H.  Landscaping and buffers. Standards as to the type, extent and placement of landscape materials and buffers as may be applicable shall be as specified in chapter 10 of this code.

8.6.6.  High density residential (R-3). 
A.  Intent. The R-3 district provides for high density residential developments near major streets and in older areas having adequate urban services with densities up to 12 dwelling units per acre consistent with the RH future land use designation of the comprehensive plan. 
B.  Permitted principal uses. Permitted principle uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
C.  Accessory uses and structures. Accessory uses and structures are limited to those uses and structures that meet the criteria of section 8.7.1. of this chapter. 
D.  Conditional uses. Conditional uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
E.  Lot and building requirements. Standards relating to lot and yard dimensions, size and placement of buildings on a lot, and density or intensity of developments shall be as specified in section 8.6.2. of this chapter. The following additional minimum requirements for townhouse projects and units shall also apply: 
1.  Project size: One-half acre. 
2.  Lot width: Twenty feet. 
3.  Lot area: Two thousand square feet. 
4.  Yard requirements: 
a.  Front: Ten feet. 
b.  Rear: Ten feet. 
c.  Side: None. 
5.  Perimeter setback: Twenty-five feet. 
6.  Minimum floor area per dwelling unit: Eight hundred square feet, plus an additional 150 square feet for each additional bedroom over two. 
7.  Maximum gross density: 12 units per acre. 
8.  Maximum lot coverage: The total lot area covered by principal and accessory buildings shall not exceed 40 percent. Swimming pools and their screen enclosures are excluded from this requirement. 
9.  Maximum building length: No principal or accessory building shall exceed 200 feet in length or width. 
10.  Maximum height: No building or structure shall exceed 35 feet in height except as allowed by section 8.7 of this code. 
11.  Building separation requirements: Building separation on any lot shall be 50 feet between building fronts or building fronts and building rears and 25 feet between any other combinations of building arrangements. 
F.  Off-street parking and loading requirements. Standards for off-street parking, loading and unloading shall be as specified in section 8.7.7. of this chapter. 
G.  Sign regulations. Standards as to the type, size and placement of signs shall be as specified in chapter 9 of this code. 
H.  Landscaping and buffers. Standards as to the type, extent and placement of landscape materials and buffers as may be applicable shall be as specified in chapter 10 of this code. 
8.6.7.  Mobile home park (MH-1). 
A.  Intent. The MH-1 district is consistent with the RM future land use designation of the comprehensive plan and recognizes the district physical characteristics of mobile home parks in the community which are designed, developed and operated under unified ownership and control. 
B.  Permitted principal uses. Permitted principle uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
C.  Accessory uses and structures. Accessory uses and structures are limited to those uses and structures that meet the criteria of section 8.7.1. of this chapter. 
D.  Conditional uses. Conditional uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
E.  Lot and building requirements. Standards relating to lot and yard dimensions, size and placement of buildings on a lot, and density or intensity of developments shall be as specified in section 8.6.2. of this chapter. The following additional standards shall also apply: 
1.  Requirements for individual mobile home spaces. 
a.  Minimum mobile home space area: Five thousand square feet. 
b.  Minimum mobile home space width: Fifty feet. 
2.  Minimum yard requirements: 
a.  Front: Fifteen feet. 
b.  Side: Five feet. 
c.  Rear: Fifteen feet. 
F.  Off-street parking and loading requirements. Standards for off-street parking and loading and unloading shall be as specified in section 8.7.7. of this chapter. 
G.  Sign regulations. Standards as to the type, size and placement of signs shall be as specified in chapter 9 of this code. 
H.  Landscaping and buffers. Standards as to the type, extent and placement of landscape materials and buffers as may be applicable shall be as specified in chapter 10 of this code. 
I.  General requirements for mobile home parks travel trailer parks. The following regulations shall apply: 
1.  Recreation area. There shall be at least one recreation area. The recreation area shall be easily accessible to all residents of the park. 
2.  Internal streets. 
a.  Two way streets shall be paved to a minimum of 20 feet and one-way streets shall be paved to a minimum of 18 feet. All streets shall be paved with materials acceptable to the city. 
b.  Parking shall be provided on each mobile home site or in paved common areas, not on streets. 
c.  Dead-end streets or streets ending in cul-de-sacs shall be limited in length to 600 feet in length and shall be provided with a turnaround having a minimum paving width diameter of 80 feet. 
3.  Entrances and exits. Entrances and exits shall be limited in number and, when combined, shall be separated with a landscaped median strip not less than five feet wide. There shall be no direct vehicle access from any space to any exterior street. 
4.  Water supply, sewage disposal and garbage and refuse handling. All mobile home and recreational vehicle parks shall comply with the applicable provisions of the Florida Administrative Code, regarding water supply, sewage disposal and garbage and refuse handling. 
8.6.8.  Office transitional (OT). 
A.  Intent. The intent of the OT district is to preserve the character of older residential areas, which are susceptible to deterioration and encroachment due to the proximity of general commercial development. The OT district is consistent with the OT future land use designation of the comprehensive plan. Certain transitional uses, including business and professional offices, are allowed on a limited basis as a means to maintain the economic viability of buildings and properties in the district by providing for alternative uses which are compatible with existing residential character. Retail sales and service establishments are discouraged in this district. 
B.  Permitted principal uses. Permitted principle uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter. 
C.  Accessory uses and structures. Accessory uses and structures are limited to those uses and structures that meet the criteria of section 8.7.1. of this chapter. 
D.  Conditional uses. Conditional uses are limited to those listed in section 8.6.1. of this chapter and the following uses are further conditioned as follows: 
1.  Government buildings, community centers, libraries, places of worship and public and private schools permitted by special exception shall have a minimum lot size of one acre. 
2.  Professional and business offices shall be limited to not more than 2,000 square feet of floor area or five off-street parking spaces, whichever is more restrictive. 
3.  Other commercial uses shall be limited to not more than 800 square feet of floor area or five parking spaces whichever is more restrictive. 
4.  The minimum lot size for office and commercial uses not otherwise located in a residential building on an existing developed lot shall be one-half acre. 
E.  Lot and building requirements. Standards relating to lot and yard dimensions, size and placement of buildings on a lot, and density or intensity of developments shall be as specified in section 8.6.2. of this chapter. 
F.  Off-street parking and loading requirements. Standards for off-street parking and loading and unloading shall be as specified in section 8.7.7. of this code. However, off-street parking required under this chapter for other than permitted residential uses shall be provided in side or rear yard areas, not in any required front yard area, nor closer to a street than the front building line. 
G.  Sign regulations. Standards as to the type, size and placement of signs shall be as specified in chapter 9 of this code. 
H.  Landscaping and buffers. Standards as to the type, extent and placement of landscape materials and buffers as may be applicable shall be as specified in chapter 10 of this code.
